intro: Brassicella erucastrum var. montana, commonly known as the mountain mustard, is a flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and hairy, alternate leaves. Native to alpine regions, this variety thrives in cool, moist environments at high elevations. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and produces small, capsule-like fruits. Its botanical features make it an important component of mountain ecosystems, supporting various pollinators and soil stability.
